defect.para: This Recall applies to 9000 Conventional and Cabover Series that have FF-981, FF-982, FF-983, FF-984, FF-986 or FF-987 non-driving front axles built from 8/7/96 through 12/16/96. This represents Navistar's builds relative to an industry recall on Meritor front axle hubs.

The front disc wheel hub flange could experience fatigue cracking under normal operating conditions. This defect could result in wheel separation that could cause a vehicular accident without warning that could result in personal injury, property damage, or both.

Owners will be notified of this campaign on their vehicles by Navistar. A listing of owner names and addresses will have been furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners to have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION AND REPLACEMENT OF THE FRONT AXLE HUB PROCEDURE

svcprocinfo.para: This issue relates to the new unitized hub and bearing assembly with no serviceable parts (bearings that are lubricated for life) referred to as a truck hub unit. All wheel hub units which require replacement must be returned along with warranty claim number and VIN identification number. Follow the instructions in the hub and stud assembly kit. Use the shipping labels and fill out the warranty claims and VIN number information. Inspect the Truck Hub Unit FIRST to Determine Whether Replacement is Necessary.

warning.para: To prevent serious eye injury, always wear safe eye protection when you perform vehicle maintenance or service.

step1.para: Check the inside area of the wheel hub unit for raised forging identification letters and numbers located on the front of the hub, in the dish area next to the hub cap. Refer to Figure 1.
If raised letters and numbers are visible on both hub units of one axle, the wheel hub units do not require replacement. Disregard remainder of this procedure.

If raised letters or numbers are not visible, inspect the inboard side (side toward center of vehicle) mounting flange to determine if hub replacement is still required. Check both hub units on each front axle. Refer to Figure 1.

warning.para: Block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving. Support the vehicle with safety stands. Do not work under a vehicle supported only by jacks. Jacks can slip or fall over and cause serious personal injury.

step1.para: Place blocks in front and behind the rear wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving. Set the parking brake. Use a jack to raise the front wheels of the vehicle from the ground and then use safety stands to support the vehicle.
Remove the tire-wheel assembly and drum to inspect the inboard side of the wheel hub unit.
Check inboard side for either (1) a continous smooth machined inner surface or (2) an inner surface with forging scallops between each wheel stud.

step2.para: The presence of a continuous smooth machined inner surface, Figure 2aand Figure 2b, (inboard side) of the wheel hub unit verifies that replacement is not required. Flange thickness will be uniform. Refer to Figure 2aand Figure 2b.

The presence of a scalloped forged surface, Figure 3a and Figure 3b, between the mounting flange stud heads indicates the wheel hub unit will require replacement. Be sure to check both hubs on each side of axle. The flange will not be uniform. Refer to Figure 3a and Figure 3b.

note.para: If one wheel hub unit has a scalloped surface on the inboard side of wheel hub unit, replace both wheel hub units on the axle.

step1.para: If both wheel hub units have a continuous smooth surface as illustrated in Figure 2a, disregard the remainder of this procedure.

svcsubproc.title: Removing the Wheel Hub Unit From the Steering Knuckle

caution.para: When the threaded protective cap is removed or tightened, use a size 3-1/2 inch socket to avoid damaging the unit.

step1.para: Remove the threaded protective cap from the hub by turning it in a counterclockwise direction.
Bend back the outer "D" lockwasher tab away from the flat edge of the outer wheel bearing nut. Refer to Figure 4.
Remove the outer wheel bearing nut and the outer washer from the axle spindle.
Use a torque multiplier or 24-inch breaker bar to remove inner wheel bearing nut and inner washer from spindle.
Discard removed hub cap, both washers and nuts.

caution.para: When removing the wheel hub unit from the knuckle spindle, take care not to misalign or wedge wheel hub unit into the spindle threads to prevent the wheel hub unit from becoming jammed or wedged onto the spindle.

step1.para: Remove wheel hub unit carefully. Draw hub assembly straight away from spindle.

note.para: If the wheel hub unit is difficult to remove from the spindle continue with the following procedures.

para.title: Using a 17.5 Ton Cross Block Puller Tool to Remove the Wheel Hub Unit from the Spindle Procedure

warning.para: Use a brass or leather mallet for removal and disassembly procedures. Do not hit steel parts with a steel hammer. Pieces can break off and cause serious personal injury.

step1.para: Using a brass hammer, remove two studs from opposite sides of the wheel hub unit to provide access for two Grade 8 bolts used with the cross block puller.
Assemble the cross block puller with two 8 inch x 7/8 inch Grade 8 bolts onto the face of the wheel hub unit assembly. Refer to Figure 5.

item.para: Always use the shortest legs possible for an application to reduce the chance of tool or equipment damage.
Apply force gradually. The part should "give" a little at a time. Do not try to speed the operation by using an impact wrench on the forcing screw.

If maximum force has been applied, and the part has not moved, use a tool with a larger capacity. Do not hit the part with a hammer in an attempt to jar it loose. Hitting the part with the hammer could result in damage to components.

step1.para: Tighten the forcing nut and washer against the cross block to apply force to the tool and separate the wheel hub unit from the knuckle spindle. Refer to Figure 6.
Repeat this procedure to remove the wheel hub unit on the opposite side of axle, if required.

svcsubproc.title: Re-installing the Replacement Wheel Hub Unit onto the Axle Spindle
svcsubproc.para: Four different kits are provided for different wheel hub unit replacement.

note.para: Two kits are required to completely service one axle.

svcsubproc.para: Long Wheel Studs are only on aluminum wheels - long wheel studs measure approximately 2.9 inches from the outboard face of the flange to the end of the stud
Short Wheel Studs are only on steel wheels - short wheel studs measure approximately 2.5 inches from the outboard face of the flange to the end of the stud

step1.para: Check the knuckle spindle for scratches, nicks or marks. Minor surface damage may be repaired using a crocus or emery cloth. Refer to Figure 7.
Clean knuckle spindle with a clean, dry rag. DO NOT apply any solvent.
Lubricate the inside bore of the replacement hub and the entire axle spindle with NLGI 1 or 2 grease.

caution.para: Take care to align unit carefully. Install the new hub unit straight onto spindle. Do not allow the hub unit to misalign and wedge onto spindle threads. Bearing damage could occur. If the wheel hub unit does not slide on easily, do not force it on the spindle. The wheel hub unit can become jammed on the spindle if care is not taken to align it properly with the spindle. If the wheel hub unit becomes jammed on the spindle, carefully remove the wheel hub unit from the spindle so as not to disassemble or loosen the inner bearings from the wheel hub unit and repeat procedures.

Disassembly of the wheel hub unit could contaminate the lubricant and will void the manufacturer's warranty. Disassembled hub units cannot be used and require replacement. Check the bore of the wheel hub unit for any obstructions and check the spindle for any nicks or burrs.

step1.para: Carefully align the new wheel hub unit bore with the spindle and then slide the hub straight onto the spindle.

warning.para: The inner wheel bearing nut and outer wheel bearing nut torque values are unique to the wheel hub unit. Failure to follow the specified torque may result in possible component damage, wheel separation and serious personal injury.

note.para: The inner wheel bearing nut and the outer wheel bearing nut are identical but torque values are different.

step1.para: Install new thick inner washer and the new wheel bearing nut onto the spindle threads. Tighten the inner wheel bearing nut onto spindle 500 to 700 ft-lbs. (678 to 949 Nm) while rotating the hub in both directions. Refer to Figure 8.
Install the new tabbed washer onto the spindle threads.
Install the new outer wheel bearing nut onto the spindle threads. Tighten the outer wheel bearing nut from 200 to 300 ft-lbs. (271 to 406 Nm) torque.

Bend tabs of the new outer replacement tabbed washer over the flats of the outer wheel bearing nut and the inner wheel bearing nut. Bend washer tabs onto at least one flat edge to each nut. Use care to ensure that tool used to bend tabs does not slip past tabs and damage the spindle hub threads.
Apply the spindle warning lable provided in the kit to the spindle end before installing the hub cap. Refer to Figure 9.
Apply a light coating of NLGI 1 or 2 grease to the axle spindle nuts to protect against corrosion.
Install the new hub cap from the kit into the hub threads. Tighten from 200 to 250 ft-lbs. (271 to 339 Nm).
Install the brake drum and the tire-wheel assembly. Refer to the International Service Manual CTS-5017K for instructions and torque specifications and tightening sequence.
All replaced wheel hub units must be returned along with warranty claim and VIN numbers, according to the instructions packaged with replacement kit. Shipping details and labels are also included.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location. Dearlers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his vehicle as soon as possible.
